issues.title: Is Signatures a relevant use case?
issues.author: ioggstream
issues.body:
## Question

The considerations in this document make me think that Signature is not a relevant use case,
at least to be mentioned in the Introduction.

While similar considerations apply to any timestamp conveyed by protocols not designed for time synchronization,
that is JWT header parameters, or Signature field parameters like `created` and `expires`,
these are better suited to convey time information related to the validity of signatures  than the `Date` header.

The same considerations will probably apply wrt avoiding replay attacks.

pulls.title: Minor comments
pulls.author: ioggstream
pulls.body:
## Preliminary feedback

- do we need to tie it to privileged actions?

- to be expanded: use cases like signatures specify a time interval, not just a timestamp... in this perspective, line 103  can be misleading.

Question:  shouldn't replay attacks to be addressed with a unique identifier ?
Probably timestamps only address the intercept and reuse (without replay) kind of attack, but this is your field :P

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
In answer to your question, yes, replay attacks usually rely on some sort of unique value to detect duplicates.  In some contexts, you have a sequence number.  For signature schemes, most use a random value [^1] that can be used for detecting duplicates.  For HPKE, the encryption contains a fresh random share for each encryption (called `enc`) that can be used for the same purpose.

I need to improve my description of anti-replay; I'll take that up separately.

[^1]: ...technically just unpredictable and probably unique

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body: Thanks Roberto.  This is better, I agree.
